title: 110_hr6701
content: The Act titled "Civil Rights Quarter Dollar Coin Act of 2008" authorizes the issuance of redesigned quarter dollars featuring prominent civil rights leaders and efforts in America. Section 5112 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow for the redesign and issuance of quarter dollars emblematic of prominent civil rights leaders and efforts in America. This follows the "Civil Rights Quarter Dollar Coin Act of 2008." The Secretary has flexibility in selecting designs for quarter dollars honoring civil rights leaders, allowing inscriptions to appear on either side of the coin. The Secretary has the flexibility to choose designs for quarter dollars honoring civil rights leaders, with inscriptions on either side of the coin. The selection of prominent civil rights leaders and events for the coins is done in consultation with various Congressional caucuses. The Secretary can choose designs for quarter dollars honoring civil rights leaders, including Martin Luther King Jr., Harriet Tubman, Rosa Parks, and others. No living individual can be featured on the coins, and a total of 40 civil rights leaders and events can be selected. The Civil Rights Quarter Dollar Coin Act of 2008 allows for the selection of 40 civil rights leaders and events to be commemorated with coins. The first 32 coin designs must be completed within 2 years of the Act's enactment, with the remaining designs finished before the end of the 2-year period after the first coin bearing the first design is issued. The designs for quarter dollars under the Civil Rights Quarter Dollar Coin Act of 2008 must be selected by the Secretary after consultation with various groups and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The Civil Rights Quarter Dollar Coin Act of 2008 mandates that quarter dollar coins depicting civil rights leaders must not depict them in a size that could be considered a '2-headed' coin. These coins will be issued at a rate of 5 new designs each year. The Secretary will select the designs after consulting with various groups and the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The Secretary of the Treasury determines the number of quarter dollars to be issued with selected designs each year. The program will continue until all civil rights leaders and events are honored with a coin. All coins minted under this program are considered numismatic items. The Secretary may mint and issue quarter dollars of each design. The Secretary determines the number of quarter dollars to be issued with selected designs each year, including silver coins with a 90% silver content. After the program ends, the design on the quarter dollar will revert to President Washington's image. The 50-State quarter dollar program will feature an image of General Washington crossing the Delaware River before the Battle of Trenton on the reverse side of the quarter dollar. SEC. 201. SILVER BULLION COIN. Section 5112 of title 31, United States Code, is amended to allow the Secretary to strike and sell bullion coins that are exact duplicates of quarter dollars, with specific characteristics such as diameter, weight, silver content, edge inscription, and denomination. These coins will not be minted or issued by the United States. The Secretary is allowed to strike and sell bullion coins that are duplicates of quarter dollars, with specific characteristics. These coins will not be minted or issued by the United States Mint in any size other than described.
